SubTopics: Provide evidence, including through the analysis of data, that plants and animals have traits inherited from parents and that variation of these traits exist in a group of similar organisms.
Content: A family breeds their two cats. The mother cat has four kittens after she mates with the father cat.
Which of the following best describes the traits that the kittens inherited?

A.Choice: All the kittens inherited traits only from the father cat.

B.Choice: All the kittens inherited traits only from the mother cat.

C.Choice: Each kitten inherited some traits from the mother cat and some traits from the father cat.

D.Choice: Two kittens inherited traits only from the mother cat and two kittens inherited traits only from the father cat.

Content: Some communication systems represent information using Morse code. Morse code uses a different pattern of dots and dashes to represent each letter of the alphabet. The table shows Morse code for three letters.
problems/MA22G5S/media/2a.jpg
Which of the following best describes the process of changing letters into Morse code?

SubTopics: Use fossils to describe types of organisms and their environments that existed long ago and compare those to living organisms and their environments. Recognize that most kinds of plants and animals that once lived on Earth are no longer found anywhere.
Content: Mastodons are extinct animals that were similar to modern-day elephants. The diagram shows the skeleton of a mastodon.
problems/MA22G5S/media/3a.jpg
Which of the following best supports a claim that mastodons lived on land?

A.Choice: The mastodon had a thick skull to protect its brain.

B.Choice: The mastodon had a large rib cage to protect its organs.

C.Choice: The mastodon had long tusks to defend against its predators.

D.Choice: The mastodon had strong leg bones to support its body weight.

SubTopics: Use a model to communicate Earth's relationship to the Sun, Moon, and other stars that explain (a) why people on Earth experience day and night, (b) patterns in daily changes in length and direction of shadows over a day, and (c) changes in the apparent position of the Sun, Moon, and stars at different times during a day, over a month, and over a year.
Content: A model of the sunlight that Earth receives is shown. Four locations on Earth are labeled W, X, Y, and Z.
problems/MA22G5S/media/4a.jpg
In which pair of locations would a person most likely be experiencing night?

SubTopics: Gather information using various informational resources on possible solutions to a design problem. Present different representations of a design solution.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
A fifth-grade class is designing a small fan that will be easy to carry. The students need to select the following parts for the fan:

:ibox:• a motor

• a power supply

• a switch

• fan blades
The students are trying to choose the best type of power supply for the fan design. Which of the following would be the best source of information?

A.Choice: a video that shows how one type of power supply works

B.Choice: a list of companies that sell different types of power supplies

C.Choice: a website that has information about different types of power supplies

D.Choice: an informational brochure about how to connect one type of power supply to a motor

Content: What should the students do to test the amount of airflow the fan will produce?

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret given data about changes in a habitat and describe how the changes may affect the ability of organisms that live in that habitat to survive and reproduce.
Content: Sea anemones are animals that live in shallow ocean environments. They can move very slowly from one place to another. A scientist investigated sea anemones by observing their behavior in a large saltwater aquarium over 15 days.

The scientist placed 10 sea anemones on the side of the aquarium that received direct, bright light. Then the scientist placed 10 other anemones on the opposite side, which had no direct light and was darker.
The graph below shows the number of sea anemones that were found on the side of the aquarium with bright light over the 15-day investigation.
problems/MA22G5S/media/6a.jpg
A dock is built along a coast where wild sea anemones live. The dock blocks most of the sunlight. Based on the results of the scientist's investigation, what will most likely happen over two weeks?

A.Choice: Most of the wild sea anemones under the dock will die off, but a few will migrate to a sunny area.

B.Choice: Most of the wild sea anemones under the dock will migrate to a sunny area, but a few will stay under the dock.

C.Choice: About 50% of the wild sea anemones under the dock will hibernate, and about 50% will migrate to a sunny area.

D.Choice: About 75% of the wild sea anemones under the dock will move around, and about 25% will migrate to a sunny area.

SubTopics: Use informational text to provide examples of improvements to existing technologies (innovations) and the development of new technologies (inventions). Recognize that technology is any modification of the natural or designed world done to fulfill human needs or wants.
Content: Over the years, technologies have been developed that allow people to communicate over long distances. Two examples of these technologies are described in the table.
problems/MA22G5S/media/7a.jpg
Which of the following best explains why the telephone was an innovation and not an invention?

B.Choice: Telephones added to what telegraphs could do.

D.Choice: Telephones allowed people to communicate over long distances.

Content: On a sunny day, a student sees a bird, as shown in the diagram.
problems/MA22G5S/media/8a.jpg
Which of the following models shows how light travels and makes it possible for the student to see the bird?

SubTopics: Plan and carry out tests of one or more design features of a given model or prototype in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify which features need to be improved. Apply the results of tests to redesign a model or prototype.
Content: The owners of a restaurant with a wooden floor want chairs that slide but do not scratch the floor. The owners test different materials on the bottom of the chair legs. They rate the materials on how well the chairs slide and whether or not they scratch the floor. The results are shown in the table.
problems/MA22G5S/media/9a.jpg
Which material will BEST allow the chairs to slide without scratching the floor?

SubTopics: Obtain and summarize information about the climate of different regions of the world to illustrate that typical weather conditions over a year vary by region.
Content: Based on the climate data table, which of the following best describes the climate of the area?

A.Choice: tundra, with low temperatures and low precipitation year round

B.Choice: tropical, with high temperatures and high precipitation year round

C.Choice: desert, with extreme high and low temperatures and very low precipitation year round

D.Choice: temperate, with changing seasonal temperatures and medium amounts of precipitation year round

SubTopics: Obtain and combine information about ways communities reduce human impact on the Earth's resources and environment by changing an agricultural, industrial, or community practice or process.
Content: Every spring, fertilizer is spread on the sports field. Some of the fertilizer runs off into a nearby stream.
Which of the following best explains why design solution 2 would be more effective than design solution 1 at reducing the amount of fertilizer entering the nearby stream?

A.Choice: In design solution 2, the fertilizer is broken down on the sports field.

B.Choice: In design solution 2, the fertilizer remains on the surface of the sports field.

C.Choice: In design solution 2, the fertilizer is absorbed by the plants in the rain garden.

D.Choice: In design solution 2, the fertilizer combines with the rainwater to become a new substance.

SubTopics: Use a particle model of matter to explain common phenomena involving gases, and phase changes between gas and liquid and between liquid and solid.
Content: Before rain falls, water particles in the air form into rain droplets. The models show water particles in three different phases.
problems/MA22G5S/media/12a.jpg
Which of the following best shows how water particles in the air form into rain droplets?

SubTopics: Use a model to describe the cycling of water through a watershed through evaporation, precipitation, absorption, surface runoff, and condensation.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
The amount of groundwater in the area near the sports field changes throughout the year.

Identify the season when the LEAST amount of water becomes groundwater in the area near the sports field. Explain why, in this season, the least amount of water becomes groundwater. Include data from the climate data table to support your answer.

Describe how design solution 1 will affect the amount of groundwater in the area near the sports field (increase, decrease, or stay the same) compared to the design of the existing field. Explain your reasoning.
Describe how design solution 2 will affect the amount of groundwater in the area near the sports field (increase, decrease, or stay the same) compared to design solution 1. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Provide evidence to explain the effect of multiple forces, including friction, on an object. Include balanced forces that do not change the motion of the object and unbalanced forces that do change the motion of the object.
Content: Two teams of students, team X and team Y, are playing tug of war, as shown. Both teams pull on the rope, but the flag in the middle does not move.
problems/MA22G5S/media/14a.jpg
The model below shows the force from team X on the rope. The force from team Y is missing. The length of the arrow represents the strength of the force.
problems/MA22G5S/media/14b.jpg
Which arrow should be added to the model to show the force from team Y on the rope?

SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to determine the nature of the forces between two magnets based on their orientations and distance relative to each other.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.

A student is investigating how magnets work. The student has two plastic toy boats. A bar magnet is placed in each boat. The poles of the magnets are not identified. The student then places the boats in a long, narrow tank of water. The sides of the tank prevent the boats from turning. The diagram shows the boats in the tank of water and a magnet in each boat.
problems/MA22G5S/media/15a.jpg
When the student places the boats near each other in the tank, they move toward each other.
Identify possible arrangements of the poles so the magnets are attracted.
Select ALL that apply.
The student replaces the magnet in one of the boats with a block of iron, as shown.
problems/MA22G5S/media/15f.jpg
Describe how the boats move after the student replaces the magnet with a block of iron. Explain your reasoning.
In the investigation, stored magnetic energy is converted into another form of energy.
Identify the form of energy that the stored magnetic energy is converted into. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Construct an argument that animals and plants have internal and external structures that support their survival, growth, behavior, and reproduction.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
The picture shows a lynx.
problems/MA22G5S/media/16a.jpg
Lynx are wild cats that have brown spotted fur, sharp claws, furry ears, and wide paws. Lynx live in forests that are cold many months of the year. They hunt rabbits and other small animals.
From the information given, identify one trait that provides camouflage for the lynx in its environment. Explain how the trait provides camouflage for the lynx.
Describe one way the claws of the lynx help it survive in its environment.

SubTopics: Obtain information to describe that energy and fuels humans use are derived from natural resources and that some energy and fuel sources are renewable and some are not.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Humans use energy and fuels in their daily lives.
Which of the following best describes the energy and fuels humans use?

A.Choice: Energy and fuels always produce electricity.

B.Choice: Energy and fuels always are made from rocks.

C.Choice: Energy and fuels always come from natural resources.

Content: Coal, wind, natural gas, and ocean tides are types of energy sources.
Which of the following tables correctly identifies the energy sources as renewable or nonrenewable energy sources?

SubTopics: Measure and graph the weights (masses) of substances before and after a reaction or phase change to provide evidence that regardless of the type of change that occurs when heating, cooling, or combining substances, the total weight (mass) of matter is conserved.
Content: A student weighs a solid piece of butter in a beaker and finds the total mass is 17 g. The student then heats the butter until it melts and measures the mass again. The diagram shows the melted butter and beaker on a scale.
problems/MA22G5S/media/18a.jpg
Which combination of weights shows the mass of the butter and beaker after the butter has melted?

SubTopics: Use simple graphical representations to show that different types of organisms have unique and diverse life cycles. Describe that all organisms have birth, growth, reproduction, and death in common but there are a variety of ways in which these happen.
Content: The table below shows some information about the life-cycle stages of four animals.
problems/MA22G5S/media/19a.jpg
Based on this information, which of the following best describes the life-cycle stages of the four animals?

A.Choice: The animals have a similar birth stage, but they each have a different lifespan.

B.Choice: The animals have a similar growth stage, but they each develop in a different way.

C.Choice: The animals have similar birth and death stages, and they all reproduce in a similar way.

D.Choice: The animals have similar birth and reproduction stages, and they all enter the adult stage at the same time.

SubTopics: Evaluate the merit of a design solution that reduces the damage caused by weather.
Content: A concrete walkway leads to the door of a school building. Wind in the area around the school typically blows from only one direction, as shown.
problems/MA22G5S/media/20a.jpg
During winter, the wind causes the walkway to become covered with snow. Which of the following solutions is the best way to keep snow off the walkway?

A.Choice: add small stones to the walkway

B.Choice: make the walkway two times wider

C.Choice: build a fence on the side of the walkway that the wind reaches first

D.Choice: set up a large fan to blow across the walkway in the opposite direction of the wind
